CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Elisabet Fura;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . At the material time she was a judge in a first - instance court in GPE . CARDINAL sets of criminal investigations were started against her , on suspicion of having repeatedly falsified official documents in the exercise of her duties , as part of an organised group , with the aim of illegally obtaining title to various properties in the centre of GPE .
CARDINAL . NORP Under the provisions of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on ORG , the applicant was automatically suspended from her post during the criminal trial .

CARDINAL . On DATE she was dismissed from her post by an order of ORG ( PERSON ) for manifest professional unfitness . On DATE the decision was endorsed by the President of the Republic and on DATE it was upheld by ORG and ORG ( former ORG ) , upon an appeal by the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor at ORG started the criminal investigations against the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested for DATE , on the orders of the prosecutor , in connection with the criminal investigations against her .
The applicant appealed against the arrest order on the grounds that it did not satisfy the domestic - law requirements or those set forth in LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the arrest order . It found that the evidence in the file disclosed a reasonable suspicion that she had committed the offences she was accused of . It considered that her actions , which were contrary to public policy , had been aggravated by the fact that the applicant had been a judge at the time .
On DATE ORG upheld the order by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL . The third judge expressed his separate opinion that there were no grounds for arresting the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the applicant 's pre - trial detention by DATE , upon a request by the prosecutor . It found that :

“ the reasons invoked – in the light of the complexity of the case which requires that the prosecutor take the investigative measures indicated in his request – constitute sufficient justification under LAW seq . of LAW . ”
On DATE ORG upheld the abovementioned interlocutory judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the applicant 's detention on the ground that the applicant 's release would be contrary to public policy , given the seriousness of the offences she was accused of and the risk of generating society 's mistrust in the judicial system .
On DATE ORG reduced the new term of detention to DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the detention for a further DATE on the ground that the reasons invoked for the arrest still existed .
On DATE ORG reduced the duration of detention to DATE again .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the detention by DATE on the same grounds , in order to allow the prosecutor to finalise the investigations . On DATE ORG upheld the interlocutory judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed a new request by the prosecutor for another extension of the applicant 's pre - trial detention , from DATE to DATE . It found that the reasons that had justified the taking of the measure did no longer exist . It noted that the applicant had been suspended from her position and pointed out that the alleged danger in terms of public policy should not be assessed in abstract terms . It also noted that the prosecutor had not made progress with the investigations after the applicant 's arrest and had not carried out the procedural measures for which he had repeatedly sought an extension of the detention .
On DATE ORG reversed the decision on the ground that the documents in the file justified the extension .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected , on the same grounds as before , another extension request .
On DATE ORG reversed the interlocutory judgment again .

CARDINAL . In the following interlocutory judgments in the case ORG did not examine the applicant 's detention , as she had been “ arrested in connection to other criminal proceedings ” ( point B below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was committed to stand trial along with several other persons . The prosecution examined some forty witnesses , documents were transferred from various authorities and several expert reports submitted .

CARDINAL . The Court of Appeal gave judgment on DATE , convicting the applicant of abuse of power and forgery and sentencing her to DATE imprisonment . The applicant 's sentence was increased to DATE imprisonment on appeal ( decision of CARDINAL DATE of ORG ) and became final on DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant was released from prison on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested by the prosecutor at ORG in connection with criminal investigations against her . The prosecutor justified his order on the grounds that the criminal offence that she had been accused of was punishable by a term of imprisonment of DATE and that her continued freedom would run counter to public policy .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was brought before ORG for examination of her appeal against the arrest order .
On DATE ORG delivered its interlocutory judgment ; it upheld the arrest order in the following terms :
“ Under the terms of the last paragraph of LAW , the court may quash the arrest order ... only if it finds that the measure was illegal .

However , in the case at hand , the [ applicant 's ] arrest meets the conditions set forth in LAW and the criteria in LAW , to ensure the proper administration of criminal proceedings ; therefore the [ applicant 's ] complaint against the arrest order seems illfounded and shall be dismissed .

Concerning the request for conditional release from arrest , in accordance with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure , the prosecutor decides on such a request during the prosecution phase and the court that examines the merits of the case deals with the request made during the criminal trial .
Therefore , the court does not have the power to examine the request , in so far as the case is currently in the prosecution phase , under the prosecutor 's exclusive supervision . ”
The court also found that the prosecutor had the power to issue the arrest order , and dismissed the applicant 's complaint to the contrary .

On DATE ORG upheld the interlocutory judgment , in particular on the ground that the reasons that had justified the imposition of the preventive measure still existed and thus the applicant 's continued detention was legal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the detention for DATE , at the prosecutor 's request . It found that :
“ the reasons invoked for taking the measure still exist , with regard to the nature of the offence , the circumstances of the facts and the consequences produced .

Moreover , the extension of the pre - trial detention is necessary , given the complexity of the case , which requires an examination of several witnesses , various expert investigations , gathering of documents from the authorities and confrontations . ”
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal and upheld the above interlocutory judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed another request by the prosecutor and refused to extend the applicant 's detention for DATE . It noted that the prosecutor had already gathered the evidence and could not justify the need for continuing the applicant 's detention ; it also found that as the applicant had been dismissed from her post , there was no longer a public - policy issue .
On CARDINAL DATE ORG reversed the above decision and extended the detention by DATE to allow the prosecutor to gather more evidence , as he had requested .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was committed for trial by the prosecutor , on charges of abuse of power and forgery , in respect of facts similar to those under investigation in the above - mentioned criminal file ( described at A above ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed a further extension request by the prosecutor and ordered the applicant 's release as it considered that the reasons for her detention did no longer exist .

DATE ORG reversed the decision ; it held that ORG had not given reasons for its decision and that the applicant 's release would still be contrary to public policy in that she had apparently committed several similar offences . It therefore extended the detention pending trial by DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the applicant 's detention by DATE on the ground that :
“ as the reasons that justified the taking of this measure still exist , releasing her would be highly contrary to public policy and would harm the investigations . ”

On DATE ORG declared inadmissible an appeal lodged by the applicant , on the ground that a decision extending detention was subject to appeal at the same time as the judgment on the merits of the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE , CARDINAL and DATE and CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE ORG extended the detention for further terms of DATE , with the same justification . On DATE , DATE and DATE ORG declared the applicant 's respective appeals inadmissible . On DATE and DATE ORG upheld on the merits the interlocutory judgments delivered by ORG .
A request by the applicant for conditional release was also dismissed by ORG , on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave judgment in the case . It convicted the applicant of abuse of power and forgery and sentenced her to DATE and DATE imprisonment . In a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the conviction but reduced the sentence to DATE and DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW concerning pre - trial detention and its extension are set forth in PERSON GPE , no . CARDINAL , § MONEY , ECHR CARDINALVI ( extracts ) . The procedure for lodging complaints against preventive measures , including pre - trial detention , is described in ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE .
